commemorations.name: All Saints' Day
commemorations.collect: Almighty God, you have knit together your elect in one communion and fellowship in the mystical Body of your Son: Give us grace so to follow your blessed saints in all virtuous and godly living, that we may come to those ineffable joys that you have prepared for those who truly love you; through Jesus Christ our Lord, who with you and the Holy Spirit lives and reigns, one God, in glory everlasting. Amen.

previous_commemoration.name: James Hannington, Bishop of Eastern Equatorial Africa and His Companions, Martyrs, 1885

next_commemoration.name: Richard Hooker, Priest and Teacher of the Faith, 1600

commemorations.name: Saturday after the Twentieth Sunday after Pentecost, or the Nineteenth Sunday after Trinity (Proper 25)
commemorations.collect: Almighty and everlasting God, you govern all things both in heaven and on earth: Mercifully hear the supplications of your people, and in our time grant us your peace; through Jesus Christ our Lord, who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever. Amen.

mass_readings.text:
A Great Multitude from Every Nation

9 After this I looked, and behold, a great multitude that no one could number, from every nation, from all tribes and peoples and languages, standing before the throne and before the Lamb, clothed in white robes, with palm branches in their hands, 10 and crying out with a loud voice, “Salvation belongs to our God who sits on the throne, and to the Lamb!” 11 And all the angels were standing around the throne and around the elders and the four living creatures, and they fell on their faces before the throne and worshiped God, 12 saying, “Amen! Blessing and glory and wisdom and thanksgiving and honor and power and might be to our God forever and ever! Amen.”

13 Then one of the elders addressed me, saying, “Who are these, clothed in white robes, and from where have they come?” 14 I said to him, “Sir, you know.” And he said to me, “These are the ones coming out of the great tribulation. They have washed their robes and made them white in the blood of the Lamb.

15 “Therefore they are before the throne of God,
    and serve him day and night in his temple;
    and he who sits on the throne will shelter them with his presence.
16 They shall hunger no more, neither thirst anymore;
    the sun shall not strike them,
    nor any scorching heat.
17 For the Lamb in the midst of the throne will be their shepherd,
    and he will guide them to springs of living water,
and God will wipe away every tear from their eyes.”

Hymn in Honor of Our Ancestors

44 Let us now praise famous men,
    and our fathers in their generations.
2 The Lord apportioned to them great glory,
    his majesty from the beginning.
3 There were those who ruled in their kingdoms,
    and were men renowned for their power,
giving counsel by their understanding,
    and proclaiming prophecies;
4 leaders of the people in their deliberations
    and in understanding of learning for the people,
    wise in their words of instruction;
5 those who composed musical tunes,
    and set forth verses in writing;
6 rich men furnished with resources,
    living peaceably in their habitations—
7 all these were honored in their generations,
    and were the glory of their times.
8 There are some of them who have left a name,
    so that men declare their praise.
9 And there are some who have no memorial,
    who have perished as though they had not lived;
they have become as though they had not been born,
    and so have their children after them.
10 But these were men of mercy,
    whose righteous deeds have not been forgotten;
11 their prosperity will remain with their descendants,
    and their inheritance to their children’s children.
12 Their descendants stand by the covenants;
    their children also, for their sake.
13 Their posterity will continue for ever,
    and their glory will not be blotted out.
14 Their bodies were buried in peace,
    and their name lives to all generations.

Psalm 149

Cantate Domino

1 Praise the Lord. O sing unto the Lord a new song;*

let the congregation of the faithful praise him.

2 Let Israel rejoice in the one who made him,*

and let the children of Zion be joyful in their King.

3 Let them praise his Name in the dance;*

let them sing praises unto him with timbrel and harp.

4 For the Lord has pleasure in his people*

and gives victory to those who are oppressed.

5 Let the faithful be joyful with glory;*

let them rejoice upon their beds.

6 Let the praises of God be in their mouth*

and a two-edged sword in their hands,

7 To inflict vengeance on the nations,*

and to rebuke the peoples,

8 To bind their kings in chains,*

and their nobles with links of iron,

9 That they may execute judgment upon them, as it is written;*

this is the honor of all his servants. Praise the Lord.

11 In him we have obtained an inheritance, having been predestined according to the purpose of him who works all things according to the counsel of his will, 12 so that we who were the first to hope in Christ might be to the praise of his glory. 13 In him you also, when you heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation, and believed in him, were sealed with the promised Holy Spirit, 14 who is the guarantee of our inheritance until we acquire possession of it, to the praise of his glory.

Thanksgiving and Prayer

15 For this reason, because I have heard of your faith in the Lord Jesus and your love toward all the saints, 16 I do not cease to give thanks for you, remembering you in my prayers, 17 that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of glory, may give you the Spirit of wisdom and of revelation in the knowledge of him, 18 having the eyes of your hearts enlightened, that you may know what is the hope to which he has called you, what are the riches of his glorious inheritance in the saints, 19 and what is the immeasurable greatness of his power toward us who believe, according to the working of his great might 20 that he worked in Christ when he raised him from the dead and seated him at his right hand in the heavenly places, 21 far above all rule and authority and power and dominion, and above every name that is named, not only in this age but also in the one to come. 22 And he put all things under his feet and gave him as head over all things to the church, 23 which is his body, the fullness of him who fills all in all.

A Great Multitude from Every Nation

9 After this I looked, and behold, a great multitude that no one could number, from every nation, from all tribes and peoples and languages, standing before the throne and before the Lamb, clothed in white robes, with palm branches in their hands, 10 and crying out with a loud voice, “Salvation belongs to our God who sits on the throne, and to the Lamb!” 11 And all the angels were standing around the throne and around the elders and the four living creatures, and they fell on their faces before the throne and worshiped God, 12 saying, “Amen! Blessing and glory and wisdom and thanksgiving and honor and power and might be to our God forever and ever! Amen.”

13 Then one of the elders addressed me, saying, “Who are these, clothed in white robes, and from where have they come?” 14 I said to him, “Sir, you know.” And he said to me, “These are the ones coming out of the great tribulation. They have washed their robes and made them white in the blood of the Lamb.

15 “Therefore they are before the throne of God,
    and serve him day and night in his temple;
    and he who sits on the throne will shelter them with his presence.
16 They shall hunger no more, neither thirst anymore;
    the sun shall not strike them,
    nor any scorching heat.
17 For the Lamb in the midst of the throne will be their shepherd,
    and he will guide them to springs of living water,
and God will wipe away every tear from their eyes.”

The Beatitudes

20 And he lifted up his eyes on his disciples, and said:

“Blessed are you who are poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.

21 “Blessed are you who are hungry now, for you shall be satisfied.

“Blessed are you who weep now, for you shall laugh.

22 “Blessed are you when people hate you and when they exclude you and revile you and spurn your name as evil, on account of the Son of Man! 23 Rejoice in that day, and leap for joy, for behold, your reward is great in heaven; for so their fathers did to the prophets.

Jesus Pronounces Woes

24 “But woe to you who are rich, for you have received your consolation.

25 “Woe to you who are full now, for you shall be hungry.

“Woe to you who laugh now, for you shall mourn and weep.

26 “Woe to you, when all people speak well of you, for so their fathers did to the false prophets.

Love Your Enemies

27 “But I say to you who hear, Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you, 28 bless those who curse you, pray for those who abuse you. 29 To one who strikes you on the cheek, offer the other also, and from one who takes away your cloak do not withhold your tunic either. 30 Give to everyone who begs from you, and from one who takes away your goods do not demand them back. 31 And as you wish that others would do to you, do so to them.

32 “If you love those who love you, what benefit is that to you? For even sinners love those who love them. 33 And if you do good to those who do good to you, what benefit is that to you? For even sinners do the same. 34 And if you lend to those from whom you expect to receive, what credit is that to you? Even sinners lend to sinners, to get back the same amount. 35 But love your enemies, and do good, and lend, expecting nothing in return, and your reward will be great, and you will be sons of the Most High, for he is kind to the ungrateful and the evil. 36 Be merciful, even as your Father is merciful.

The Sermon on the Mount

5 Seeing the crowds, he went up on the mountain, and when he sat down, his disciples came to him.

The Beatitudes

2 And he opened his mouth and taught them, saying:

3 “Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

4 “Blessed are those who mourn, for they shall be comforted.

5 “Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth.

6 “Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they shall be satisfied.

7 “Blessed are the merciful, for they shall receive mercy.

8 “Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God.

9 “Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God.

10 “Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness' sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

11 “Blessed are you when others revile you and persecute you and utter all kinds of evil against you falsely on my account. 12 Rejoice and be glad, for your reward is great in heaven, for so they persecuted the prophets who were before you.

commemorations.name: Commemoration of the Faithful Departed
commemorations.collect: Almighty God, by your Holy Spirit you have made us one with your saints in heaven and on earth: Grant that in our earthly pilgrimage we may always be supported by this fellowship of love and prayer, and know ourselves to be surrounded by their witness to your power and mercy; for the sake of Jesus Christ, in whom all our intercessions are acceptable through the Spirit, and who lives and reigns with you and the same Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.

mass_readings.text:
10 Hear the word of the Lord,
    you rulers of Sodom!
Give ear to the teaching of our God,
    you people of Gomorrah!
11 “What to me is the multitude of your sacrifices?
    says the Lord;
I have had enough of burnt offerings of rams
    and the fat of well-fed beasts;
I do not delight in the blood of bulls,
    or of lambs, or of goats.

12 “When you come to appear before me,
    who has required of you
    this trampling of my courts?
13 Bring no more vain offerings;
    incense is an abomination to me.
New moon and Sabbath and the calling of convocations—
    I cannot endure iniquity and solemn assembly.
14 Your new moons and your appointed feasts
    my soul hates;
they have become a burden to me;
    I am weary of bearing them.
15 When you spread out your hands,
    I will hide my eyes from you;
even though you make many prayers,
    I will not listen;
    your hands are full of blood.
16 Wash yourselves; make yourselves clean;
    remove the evil of your deeds from before my eyes;
cease to do evil,
17     learn to do good;
seek justice,
    correct oppression;
bring justice to the fatherless,
    plead the widow's cause.

18 “Come now, let us reason together, says the Lord:
though your sins are like scarlet,
    they shall be as white as snow;
though they are red like crimson,
    they shall become like wool.
19 If you are willing and obedient,
    you shall eat the good of the land;
20 but if you refuse and rebel,
    you shall be eaten by the sword;
    for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.”

Psalm 32

Beati quorum

1 Blessed is the one whose unrighteousness is forgiven,*

and whose sin is covered.

2 Blessed is the one to whom the Lord imputes no sin,*

and in whose spirit there is no guile.

3 For while I held my tongue, my bones wasted away;*

I ceased not from groaning all the day long.

4 For your hand was heavy upon me day and night,*

and I was dried up and withered, as in the drought of summer.

5 Then I acknowledged my sin unto you,*

and I did not hide my iniquity.

6 I said, "I will confess my sins unto the Lord";*

and so you forgave the wickedness of my sin.

7 For this reason shall all the godly make their prayers unto you at a time when you may be found;*

when the great floodwaters rise, they shall not reach them.

8 You are my hiding-place; you shall preserve me from trouble;*

you shall encompass me with songs of deliverance.

9 "I will instruct you and teach you in the way that you should go,*

and I will guide you with my eye.

10 Do not be like the horse and mule, which have no understanding,*

whose mouths must be held with bit and bridle, or else they will not come near you."

11 Great troubles remain for the ungodly;*

but mercy embraces those who trust in the Lord.

12 Be glad, O you righteous, and rejoice in the Lord;*

and be joyful, all who are true of heart.

Greeting

1 Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy,

To the church of the Thessalonians in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ:

2 Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

Thanksgiving

3 We ought always to give thanks to God for you, brothers, as is right, because your faith is growing abundantly, and the love of every one of you for one another is increasing. 4 Therefore we ourselves boast about you in the churches of God for your steadfastness and faith in all your persecutions and in the afflictions that you are enduring.

The Judgment at Christ's Coming

5 This is evidence of the righteous judgment of God, that you may be considered worthy of the kingdom of God, for which you are also suffering— 6 since indeed God considers it just to repay with affliction those who afflict you, 7 and to grant relief to you who are afflicted as well as to us, when the Lord Jesus is revealed from heaven with his mighty angels 8 in flaming fire, inflicting vengeance on those who do not know God and on those who do not obey the gospel of our Lord Jesus. 9 They will suffer the punishment of eternal destruction, away from the presence of the Lord and from the glory of his might, 10 when he comes on that day to be glorified in his saints, and to be marveled at among all who have believed, because our testimony to you was believed. 11 To this end we always pray for you, that our God may make you worthy of his calling and may fulfill every resolve for good and every work of faith by his power, 12 so that the name of our Lord Jesus may be glorified in you, and you in him, according to the grace of our God and the Lord Jesus Christ.

Jesus and Zacchaeus

19 He entered Jericho and was passing through. 2 And behold, there was a man named Zacchaeus. He was a chief tax collector and was rich. 3 And he was seeking to see who Jesus was, but on account of the crowd he could not, because he was small in stature. 4 So he ran on ahead and climbed up into a sycamore tree to see him, for he was about to pass that way. 5 And when Jesus came to the place, he looked up and said to him, “Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for I must stay at your house today.” 6 So he hurried and came down and received him joyfully. 7 And when they saw it, they all grumbled, “He has gone in to be the guest of a man who is a sinner.” 8 And Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, “Behold, Lord, the half of my goods I give to the poor. And if I have defrauded anyone of anything, I restore it fourfold.” 9 And Jesus said to him, “Today salvation has come to this house, since he also is a son of Abraham. 10 For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.”

commemorations.name: Richard Hooker, Priest and Teacher of the Faith, 1600
commemorations.collect: Almighty God, you gave your servant Richard Hooker special gifts of grace to understand and teach the truth revealed in Christ Jesus: Grant that by this teaching we may know you, the one true God, and Jesus Christ whom you have sent; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.
ai_bullet_points: Born in 1554 near Exeter, Richard Hooker became one of the most influential English theologians of the 16th century[1][4].
He wrote "Of the Laws of Ecclesiastical Polity," a seminal work defending the Church of England's structure and practices against Puritan criticisms[3][4].
Hooker developed the Anglican approach of balancing Scripture, tradition, and reason in theological reflection, which became foundational for Anglican thought[2].
He articulated the concept of the "via media" or middle way between Protestantism and Catholicism, shaping Anglican identity[2][5].
Hooker's emphasis on natural law, reason, and moderation in theological disputes influenced later Anglican theology and political philosophy[3][4].
He served as Master of the Temple in London and as a country rector, dying in 1600 at Bishopsbourne near Canterbury[4][8].
commemorations.ai_hagiography: Richard Hooker, born in March 1554 near Exeter, Devon, was a towering figure in Anglican theology whose influence continues to shape the Church of England and the wider Anglican Communion to this day. Raised in humble circumstances, Hooker's exceptional intellect was recognized early by his uncle, John Hooker, who secured the patronage of Bishop John Jewel of Salisbury. This connection paved the way for young Richard to attend Corpus Christi College, Oxford, in 1569[1][2]. At Oxford, Hooker distinguished himself as a brilliant scholar, particularly in Hebrew, Greek, and music. His academic prowess led to his appointment as a fellow of Corpus Christi College in 1577 and later as deputy professor of Hebrew. Hooker's time at Oxford was marked by intense study and reflection on theological matters, laying the foundation for his future works[2][3]. Ordained to the priesthood in 1581, Hooker's career took a significant turn in 1585 when he was appointed Master of the Temple Church in London. It was here that Hooker engaged in a pivotal theological controversy with Walter Travers, a prominent Puritan. Their debates, which became known as the "Battle of the Pulpits," centered on the nature of salvation and the role of reason in matters of faith. This conflict spurred Hooker to begin work on his magnum opus, "Of the Laws of Ecclesiastical Polity"[1][3]. Seeking a quieter environment to write, Hooker moved to the country parish of Boscombe in 1591. It was here that he composed the first five books of the "Laws," a work that would become foundational to Anglican theology. In this treatise, Hooker articulated a vision of Anglicanism that balanced Scripture, tradition, and reason, offering a middle way between Roman Catholicism and extreme Protestantism[1][4]. Hooker's "Laws" presented a sophisticated defense of the Elizabethan Settlement and the Church of England's practices. He argued for the importance of natural law, reason, and tradition alongside Scripture in shaping church polity and theology. His work was groundbreaking in its scope and depth, addressing not only ecclesiastical matters but also providing a comprehensive philosophy of law and governance[4][6]. In his final years, Hooker served as rector of Bishopsbourne near Canterbury, where he completed the fifth book of the "Laws" and continued work on the remaining volumes. Though he did not live to see the publication of the final three books, his impact on Anglican thought was already profound. Richard Hooker passed away on November 2, 1600, leaving a legacy as one of the greatest theologians in English history. His work continues to be studied and revered, with his statue standing in Exeter Cathedral Close as a testament to his enduring influence on Anglican theology and the Church of England[1][6][9].
commemorations.ai_legend: In 1585, Richard Hooker preached a sermon at the Temple Church in London that sparked great controversy. He dared to suggest that God, in His infinite mercy, might have saved many Roman Catholics who lived before the Reformation, even though they held to some erroneous beliefs. This compassionate view enraged some of the more zealous Puritans in attendance. They saw Hooker's words as a dangerous compromise with "popery" and a betrayal of Protestant principles. Murmurs of discontent spread through the congregation. Undeterred, Hooker calmly continued his sermon. With eloquence and scriptural wisdom, he expounded on God's boundless grace that can overcome human ignorance and error. He argued that while the Roman Church taught some false doctrines, many ordinary Catholics of earlier times had a sincere, if imperfect, faith in Christ. "God, I doubt not, was merciful to save thousands of them, though they lived in popish superstitions, inasmuch as they sinned ignorantly," Hooker declared[3]. He went on to say that even if someone holds faith "but weakly and as it were by a slender thread," God may still smile upon that faith and save the soul[3]. In the days that followed, Hooker faced harsh criticism from hardliners who accused him of being soft on "papists." Yet he stood firm in his convictions, responding to attacks with patience and carefully reasoned arguments from Scripture and church history. This incident revealed Hooker's deeply merciful spirit and his refusal to place limits on God's saving power. It also demonstrated his courage in challenging the rigid certainties of some of his fellow Protestants. Above all, it showed his commitment to pursuing theological truth with both intellectual rigor and pastoral sensitivity.
commemorations.ai_lesser_feasts_and_fasts: In any list of Anglican theologians, Richard Hooker’s name would stand high, if not first. He was born in 1553 at Heavitree, near Exeter, and was admitted in 1567 to Corpus Christi College, Oxford, of which he became a Fellow ten years later. After ordination and marriage in 1581, he held a living in Buckinghamshire. In 1586, he became Master of the Temple, in London. Later, he served country parishes in Boscombe, Salisbury, and Bishopsbourne near Canterbury. A controversy with a noted Puritan led Hooker to prepare a comprehensive defense of the Reformation settlement under Queen Elizabeth I. This work, his masterpiece, was entitled The Laws of Ecclesiastical Polity. Its philosophical base is Aristotelian, with a strong emphasis upon natural law eternally planted by God in creation. On this foundation, all positive laws of church and state are grounded—from Scriptural revelation, tradition, and reason. Book Five of the Laws is a massive defense of the Book of Common Prayer, directed primarily against Puritan detractors. Hooker’s arguments are buttressed by enormous patristic learning, but the needs of the contemporary worshiper are paramount, and he draws effectively on his twenty-year experience of using the Prayer Book. Concerning the nature of the church, Hooker wrote: “The church is always a visible society of men; not an assembly, but a society. For although the name of the church be given unto Christian assemblies, although any multitude of Christian men congregated may be termed by the name of a church, yet assemblies properly are rather things that belong to a church. Men are assembled for performance of public actions; which actions being ended, the assembly dissolveth itself and is no longer in being, whereas the church which was assembled doth no less continue afterwards than before.” Pope Clement VIII is reported to have said that Hooker’s work “had in it such seeds of eternity that it would abide until the last fire shall consume all learning”.
commemorations.ai_one_sentence: Richard Hooker (1554-1600) was an influential English priest, theologian, and apologist who is known as the preeminent theorist of Anglican theology, particularly for his defense of the Church of England against Puritan criticisms and his emphasis on Scripture, tradition, and reason as the foundations of Anglican thought.
commemorations.ai_quote: "Of Law there can be no less acknowledged, than that her seat is the bosom of God, her voice the harmony of the world: all things in heaven and earth do her homage, the very least as feeling her care, and the greatest as not exempted from her power."[4]
commemorations.ai_verse: "All Scripture is breathed out by God and profitable for teaching, for reproof, for correction, and for training in righteousness"

evening_commemorations.collect: Almighty God, you gave your servant Richard Hooker special gifts of grace to understand and teach the truth revealed in Christ Jesus: Grant that by this teaching we may know you, the one true God, and Jesus Christ whom you have sent; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.
ai_bullet_points: Born in 1554 near Exeter, Richard Hooker became one of the most influential English theologians of the 16th century[1][4].
He wrote "Of the Laws of Ecclesiastical Polity," a seminal work defending the Church of England's structure and practices against Puritan criticisms[3][4].
Hooker developed the Anglican approach of balancing Scripture, tradition, and reason in theological reflection, which became foundational for Anglican thought[2].
He articulated the concept of the "via media" or middle way between Protestantism and Catholicism, shaping Anglican identity[2][5].
Hooker's emphasis on natural law, reason, and moderation in theological disputes influenced later Anglican theology and political philosophy[3][4].
He served as Master of the Temple in London and as a country rector, dying in 1600 at Bishopsbourne near Canterbury[4][8].
evening_commemorations.ai_hagiography: Richard Hooker, born in March 1554 near Exeter, Devon, was a towering figure in Anglican theology whose influence continues to shape the Church of England and the wider Anglican Communion to this day. Raised in humble circumstances, Hooker's exceptional intellect was recognized early by his uncle, John Hooker, who secured the patronage of Bishop John Jewel of Salisbury. This connection paved the way for young Richard to attend Corpus Christi College, Oxford, in 1569[1][2]. At Oxford, Hooker distinguished himself as a brilliant scholar, particularly in Hebrew, Greek, and music. His academic prowess led to his appointment as a fellow of Corpus Christi College in 1577 and later as deputy professor of Hebrew. Hooker's time at Oxford was marked by intense study and reflection on theological matters, laying the foundation for his future works[2][3]. Ordained to the priesthood in 1581, Hooker's career took a significant turn in 1585 when he was appointed Master of the Temple Church in London. It was here that Hooker engaged in a pivotal theological controversy with Walter Travers, a prominent Puritan. Their debates, which became known as the "Battle of the Pulpits," centered on the nature of salvation and the role of reason in matters of faith. This conflict spurred Hooker to begin work on his magnum opus, "Of the Laws of Ecclesiastical Polity"[1][3]. Seeking a quieter environment to write, Hooker moved to the country parish of Boscombe in 1591. It was here that he composed the first five books of the "Laws," a work that would become foundational to Anglican theology. In this treatise, Hooker articulated a vision of Anglicanism that balanced Scripture, tradition, and reason, offering a middle way between Roman Catholicism and extreme Protestantism[1][4]. Hooker's "Laws" presented a sophisticated defense of the Elizabethan Settlement and the Church of England's practices. He argued for the importance of natural law, reason, and tradition alongside Scripture in shaping church polity and theology. His work was groundbreaking in its scope and depth, addressing not only ecclesiastical matters but also providing a comprehensive philosophy of law and governance[4][6]. In his final years, Hooker served as rector of Bishopsbourne near Canterbury, where he completed the fifth book of the "Laws" and continued work on the remaining volumes. Though he did not live to see the publication of the final three books, his impact on Anglican thought was already profound. Richard Hooker passed away on November 2, 1600, leaving a legacy as one of the greatest theologians in English history. His work continues to be studied and revered, with his statue standing in Exeter Cathedral Close as a testament to his enduring influence on Anglican theology and the Church of England[1][6][9].
evening_commemorations.ai_legend: In 1585, Richard Hooker preached a sermon at the Temple Church in London that sparked great controversy. He dared to suggest that God, in His infinite mercy, might have saved many Roman Catholics who lived before the Reformation, even though they held to some erroneous beliefs. This compassionate view enraged some of the more zealous Puritans in attendance. They saw Hooker's words as a dangerous compromise with "popery" and a betrayal of Protestant principles. Murmurs of discontent spread through the congregation. Undeterred, Hooker calmly continued his sermon. With eloquence and scriptural wisdom, he expounded on God's boundless grace that can overcome human ignorance and error. He argued that while the Roman Church taught some false doctrines, many ordinary Catholics of earlier times had a sincere, if imperfect, faith in Christ. "God, I doubt not, was merciful to save thousands of them, though they lived in popish superstitions, inasmuch as they sinned ignorantly," Hooker declared[3]. He went on to say that even if someone holds faith "but weakly and as it were by a slender thread," God may still smile upon that faith and save the soul[3]. In the days that followed, Hooker faced harsh criticism from hardliners who accused him of being soft on "papists." Yet he stood firm in his convictions, responding to attacks with patience and carefully reasoned arguments from Scripture and church history. This incident revealed Hooker's deeply merciful spirit and his refusal to place limits on God's saving power. It also demonstrated his courage in challenging the rigid certainties of some of his fellow Protestants. Above all, it showed his commitment to pursuing theological truth with both intellectual rigor and pastoral sensitivity.
evening_commemorations.ai_lesser_feasts_and_fasts: In any list of Anglican theologians, Richard Hooker’s name would stand high, if not first. He was born in 1553 at Heavitree, near Exeter, and was admitted in 1567 to Corpus Christi College, Oxford, of which he became a Fellow ten years later. After ordination and marriage in 1581, he held a living in Buckinghamshire. In 1586, he became Master of the Temple, in London. Later, he served country parishes in Boscombe, Salisbury, and Bishopsbourne near Canterbury. A controversy with a noted Puritan led Hooker to prepare a comprehensive defense of the Reformation settlement under Queen Elizabeth I. This work, his masterpiece, was entitled The Laws of Ecclesiastical Polity. Its philosophical base is Aristotelian, with a strong emphasis upon natural law eternally planted by God in creation. On this foundation, all positive laws of church and state are grounded—from Scriptural revelation, tradition, and reason. Book Five of the Laws is a massive defense of the Book of Common Prayer, directed primarily against Puritan detractors. Hooker’s arguments are buttressed by enormous patristic learning, but the needs of the contemporary worshiper are paramount, and he draws effectively on his twenty-year experience of using the Prayer Book. Concerning the nature of the church, Hooker wrote: “The church is always a visible society of men; not an assembly, but a society. For although the name of the church be given unto Christian assemblies, although any multitude of Christian men congregated may be termed by the name of a church, yet assemblies properly are rather things that belong to a church. Men are assembled for performance of public actions; which actions being ended, the assembly dissolveth itself and is no longer in being, whereas the church which was assembled doth no less continue afterwards than before.” Pope Clement VIII is reported to have said that Hooker’s work “had in it such seeds of eternity that it would abide until the last fire shall consume all learning”.
evening_commemorations.ai_one_sentence: Richard Hooker (1554-1600) was an influential English priest, theologian, and apologist who is known as the preeminent theorist of Anglican theology, particularly for his defense of the Church of England against Puritan criticisms and his emphasis on Scripture, tradition, and reason as the foundations of Anglican thought.
evening_commemorations.ai_quote: "Of Law there can be no less acknowledged, than that her seat is the bosom of God, her voice the harmony of the world: all things in heaven and earth do her homage, the very least as feeling her care, and the greatest as not exempted from her power."[4]
evening_commemorations.ai_verse: "All Scripture is breathed out by God and profitable for teaching, for reproof, for correction, and for training in righteousness"

mass_readings.text:
10 Hear the word of the Lord,
    you rulers of Sodom!
Give ear to the teaching of our God,
    you people of Gomorrah!
11 “What to me is the multitude of your sacrifices?
    says the Lord;
I have had enough of burnt offerings of rams
    and the fat of well-fed beasts;
I do not delight in the blood of bulls,
    or of lambs, or of goats.

12 “When you come to appear before me,
    who has required of you
    this trampling of my courts?
13 Bring no more vain offerings;
    incense is an abomination to me.
New moon and Sabbath and the calling of convocations—
    I cannot endure iniquity and solemn assembly.
14 Your new moons and your appointed feasts
    my soul hates;
they have become a burden to me;
    I am weary of bearing them.
15 When you spread out your hands,
    I will hide my eyes from you;
even though you make many prayers,
    I will not listen;
    your hands are full of blood.
16 Wash yourselves; make yourselves clean;
    remove the evil of your deeds from before my eyes;
cease to do evil,
17     learn to do good;
seek justice,
    correct oppression;
bring justice to the fatherless,
    plead the widow's cause.

18 “Come now, let us reason together, says the Lord:
though your sins are like scarlet,
    they shall be as white as snow;
though they are red like crimson,
    they shall become like wool.
19 If you are willing and obedient,
    you shall eat the good of the land;
20 but if you refuse and rebel,
    you shall be eaten by the sword;
    for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.”

Psalm 32

Beati quorum

1 Blessed is the one whose unrighteousness is forgiven,*

and whose sin is covered.

2 Blessed is the one to whom the Lord imputes no sin,*

and in whose spirit there is no guile.

3 For while I held my tongue, my bones wasted away;*

I ceased not from groaning all the day long.

4 For your hand was heavy upon me day and night,*

and I was dried up and withered, as in the drought of summer.

5 Then I acknowledged my sin unto you,*

and I did not hide my iniquity.

6 I said, "I will confess my sins unto the Lord";*

and so you forgave the wickedness of my sin.

7 For this reason shall all the godly make their prayers unto you at a time when you may be found;*

when the great floodwaters rise, they shall not reach them.

8 You are my hiding-place; you shall preserve me from trouble;*

you shall encompass me with songs of deliverance.

9 "I will instruct you and teach you in the way that you should go,*

and I will guide you with my eye.

10 Do not be like the horse and mule, which have no understanding,*

whose mouths must be held with bit and bridle, or else they will not come near you."

11 Great troubles remain for the ungodly;*

but mercy embraces those who trust in the Lord.

12 Be glad, O you righteous, and rejoice in the Lord;*

and be joyful, all who are true of heart.

Greeting

1 Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy,

To the church of the Thessalonians in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ:

2 Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

Thanksgiving

3 We ought always to give thanks to God for you, brothers, as is right, because your faith is growing abundantly, and the love of every one of you for one another is increasing. 4 Therefore we ourselves boast about you in the churches of God for your steadfastness and faith in all your persecutions and in the afflictions that you are enduring.

The Judgment at Christ's Coming

5 This is evidence of the righteous judgment of God, that you may be considered worthy of the kingdom of God, for which you are also suffering— 6 since indeed God considers it just to repay with affliction those who afflict you, 7 and to grant relief to you who are afflicted as well as to us, when the Lord Jesus is revealed from heaven with his mighty angels 8 in flaming fire, inflicting vengeance on those who do not know God and on those who do not obey the gospel of our Lord Jesus. 9 They will suffer the punishment of eternal destruction, away from the presence of the Lord and from the glory of his might, 10 when he comes on that day to be glorified in his saints, and to be marveled at among all who have believed, because our testimony to you was believed. 11 To this end we always pray for you, that our God may make you worthy of his calling and may fulfill every resolve for good and every work of faith by his power, 12 so that the name of our Lord Jesus may be glorified in you, and you in him, according to the grace of our God and the Lord Jesus Christ.

Jesus and Zacchaeus

19 He entered Jericho and was passing through. 2 And behold, there was a man named Zacchaeus. He was a chief tax collector and was rich. 3 And he was seeking to see who Jesus was, but on account of the crowd he could not, because he was small in stature. 4 So he ran on ahead and climbed up into a sycamore tree to see him, for he was about to pass that way. 5 And when Jesus came to the place, he looked up and said to him, “Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for I must stay at your house today.” 6 So he hurried and came down and received him joyfully. 7 And when they saw it, they all grumbled, “He has gone in to be the guest of a man who is a sinner.” 8 And Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, “Behold, Lord, the half of my goods I give to the poor. And if I have defrauded anyone of anything, I restore it fourfold.” 9 And Jesus said to him, “Today salvation has come to this house, since he also is a son of Abraham. 10 For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.”

commemorations.name: Tuesday after the Twenty-first Sunday after Pentecost, or the Twentieth Sunday after Trinity (Proper 26)
commemorations.collect: Grant us, Lord, not to be anxious about earthly things, but to love things heavenly; and even now, as we live among things that are passing away, to hold fast to those that shall endure; through Jesus Christ our Lord, who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever. Amen.

commemorations.name: Elizabeth and Zechariah, Parents of John the Baptist
commemorations.collect: Almighty God, by your Holy Spirit you have made us one with your saints in heaven and on earth: Grant that in our earthly pilgrimage we may always be supported by this fellowship of love and prayer, and know ourselves to be surrounded by their witness to your power and mercy; for the sake of Jesus Christ, in whom all our intercessions are acceptable through the Spirit, and who lives and reigns with you and the same Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.
ai_bullet_points: Zechariah and Elizabeth were righteous, elderly priests from Aaron's lineage who faithfully served God despite being childless[1][4].
An angel appeared to Zechariah, announcing Elizabeth would bear a son named John, who would prepare people for the Lord[3][7].
Elizabeth conceived and gave birth to John the Baptist in her old age, demonstrating God's miraculous power[2][4].
Their story exemplifies faithful waiting, trust in God's timing, and the fulfillment of divine promises[5][10].
Both Zechariah and Elizabeth prophesied under the influence of the Holy Spirit about John's role as the forerunner of Christ[7][10].
They raised John "in the nurture and admonition of the Lord," preparing him for his prophetic ministry[10].
ai_foods: Italy: Gnocchi di San Giovanni (dumplings) served in Tuscany on June 24th[6]
Lebanon: Feast of Mar Youhanna (St. John) celebrated with kibbeh (meat and bulgur wheat dish)[7]
Malta: Fenkata (rabbit stew) traditionally eaten on June 24th[7]
Spain: Bonfires lit and herbs collected on St. John's Eve (June 23rd) to flavor foods[7]
Armenia: Blessing of grapes ceremony on the Sunday nearest August 15th, associated with St. John the Baptist[7]
commemorations.ai_hagiography: Elizabeth and Zechariah were righteous servants of God, living in Judea during the reign of King Herod. Both were descendants of Aaron, the first high priest of Israel, and Zechariah served as a priest in the temple. The Gospel of Luke describes them as "righteous before God, walking blamelessly in all the commandments and statutes of the Lord" (Luke 1:6)[1]. Despite their faithfulness, they faced the sorrow of childlessness, as Elizabeth was barren and both were advanced in years[1][2]. God's miraculous intervention in their lives began when Zechariah was chosen by lot to enter the temple of the Lord and burn incense. While performing this sacred duty, the angel Gabriel appeared to him, standing at the right side of the altar of incense. Gabriel announced that Elizabeth would bear a son, whom they were to name John. This child would be filled with the Holy Spirit even from birth and would go before the Lord "in the spirit and power of Elijah" (Luke 1:17)[2]. Zechariah, overwhelmed by the angel's message, doubted the possibility of such a miracle given their advanced age. As a consequence of his unbelief, Gabriel declared that Zechariah would be unable to speak until the day these things took place. When Zechariah emerged from the temple, he was indeed mute, able only to make signs to the people who realized he had seen a vision[2]. In due time, Elizabeth conceived and spent five months in seclusion, rejoicing that the Lord had taken away her reproach among the people. In her sixth month of pregnancy, she was visited by her relative Mary, who had just received her own angelic announcement about the birth of Jesus. Upon Mary's arrival, the baby in Elizabeth's womb leaped, and Elizabeth, filled with the Holy Spirit, blessed Mary and her unborn child[2][4]. When Elizabeth gave birth to her son, friends and relatives gathered to celebrate, assuming the child would be named after his father. However, Elizabeth insisted that his name was to be John, as the angel had instructed. When they turned to Zechariah for confirmation, he wrote on a tablet, "His name is John." Immediately, Zechariah's speech was restored, and he began praising God. Filled with the Holy Spirit, he prophesied about his son's role as the forerunner of the Messiah in what is now known as the Benedictus (Luke 1:68-79)[2][5]. Elizabeth and Zechariah's faithfulness was rewarded not only with a son in their old age but with the privilege of raising the prophet who would prepare the way for the Lord. Their story exemplifies God's faithfulness to His promises and His power to work miracles even in the most unlikely circumstances. John grew up to become John the Baptist, fulfilling the angel's prophecy by calling people to repentance and baptizing them, including Jesus himself. Elizabeth and Zechariah's legacy lives on through their son's pivotal role in salvation history and their own example of unwavering faith in the face of doubt and difficulty[5][6].
commemorations.ai_legend: Zechariah stood before the altar, his hands trembling as he held the censer. The weight of his priestly duties felt heavier than usual, for today he had been chosen by lot to enter the sanctuary and burn incense before the Lord. As the fragrant smoke rose, Zechariah's heart was filled with a mixture of awe and sorrow. He and his beloved wife Elizabeth had prayed for years for a child, but now in their old age, hope seemed lost. Suddenly, a brilliant light filled the sanctuary, and an angel appeared at the right side of the altar. Zechariah stumbled backward, his eyes wide with fear. The angel spoke, his voice resonating with divine authority: "Do not be afraid, Zechariah. Your prayer has been heard. Your wife Elizabeth will bear you a son, and you shall call his name John." Zechariah's mind reeled. Could it be true? After all these years? His doubt bubbled to the surface, and he questioned the angel: "How shall I know this? For I am an old man, and my wife is advanced in years." The angel's countenance grew stern. "I am Gabriel. I stand in the presence of God, and I was sent to speak to you and to bring you this good news. And behold, you will be silent and unable to speak until the day that these things take place, because you did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their time." In an instant, Zechariah felt his tongue grow heavy and immobile. As he left the sanctuary, he could only gesture to the waiting crowd, unable to share the miraculous news. For nine long months, Zechariah remained silent. Yet in that silence, his faith grew. He watched in wonder as Elizabeth's belly swelled with new life. He saw the joy in her eyes and felt the kicks of their unborn son. In the quiet of his heart, Zechariah's doubt transformed into unwavering trust in God's promise. When the child was born and the time came to name him, Zechariah's relatives assumed the boy would bear his father's name. But Elizabeth insisted, "No; he shall be called John." Confused, they turned to Zechariah, who asked for a writing tablet. With a steady hand, he wrote, "His name is John." At that moment, Zechariah's tongue was loosed, and he began to speak, praising God. The words that had been bottled up for months poured forth in a beautiful prophecy, blessing the Lord and foretelling the great purpose of his son's life. Zechariah's faithful silence had prepared him for this moment of joyous proclamation. Through his experience, he learned that God's promises, no matter how impossible they may seem, are always fulfilled in His perfect time.
commemorations.ai_one_sentence: Elizabeth and Zechariah were the righteous and devout parents of John the Baptist, known for their faithfulness to God despite years of childlessness, and their role in raising the prophetic forerunner who prepared the way for Jesus Christ.
commemorations.ai_quote: "Both of them were righteous before God, walking blamelessly in all the commandments and statutes of the Lord."[1][2][5]
commemorations.ai_verse: "And they were both righteous before God, walking blamelessly in all the commandments and statutes of the Lord."

Spain: Bonfires lit and herbs collected on St. John's Eve (June 23rd) to flavor foods[7]
Armenia: Blessing of grapes ceremony on the Sunday nearest August 15th, associated with St. John the Baptist[7]
evening_commemorations.ai_hagiography: Elizabeth and Zechariah were righteous servants of God, living in Judea during the reign of King Herod. Both were descendants of Aaron, the first high priest of Israel, and Zechariah served as a priest in the temple. The Gospel of Luke describes them as "righteous before God, walking blamelessly in all the commandments and statutes of the Lord" (Luke 1:6)[1]. Despite their faithfulness, they faced the sorrow of childlessness, as Elizabeth was barren and both were advanced in years[1][2]. God's miraculous intervention in their lives began when Zechariah was chosen by lot to enter the temple of the Lord and burn incense. While performing this sacred duty, the angel Gabriel appeared to him, standing at the right side of the altar of incense. Gabriel announced that Elizabeth would bear a son, whom they were to name John. This child would be filled with the Holy Spirit even from birth and would go before the Lord "in the spirit and power of Elijah" (Luke 1:17)[2]. Zechariah, overwhelmed by the angel's message, doubted the possibility of such a miracle given their advanced age. As a consequence of his unbelief, Gabriel declared that Zechariah would be unable to speak until the day these things took place. When Zechariah emerged from the temple, he was indeed mute, able only to make signs to the people who realized he had seen a vision[2]. In due time, Elizabeth conceived and spent five months in seclusion, rejoicing that the Lord had taken away her reproach among the people. In her sixth month of pregnancy, she was visited by her relative Mary, who had just received her own angelic announcement about the birth of Jesus. Upon Mary's arrival, the baby in Elizabeth's womb leaped, and Elizabeth, filled with the Holy Spirit, blessed Mary and her unborn child[2][4]. When Elizabeth gave birth to her son, friends and relatives gathered to celebrate, assuming the child would be named after his father. However, Elizabeth insisted that his name was to be John, as the angel had instructed. When they turned to Zechariah for confirmation, he wrote on a tablet, "His name is John." Immediately, Zechariah's speech was restored, and he began praising God. Filled with the Holy Spirit, he prophesied about his son's role as the forerunner of the Messiah in what is now known as the Benedictus (Luke 1:68-79)[2][5]. Elizabeth and Zechariah's faithfulness was rewarded not only with a son in their old age but with the privilege of raising the prophet who would prepare the way for the Lord. Their story exemplifies God's faithfulness to His promises and His power to work miracles even in the most unlikely circumstances. John grew up to become John the Baptist, fulfilling the angel's prophecy by calling people to repentance and baptizing them, including Jesus himself. Elizabeth and Zechariah's legacy lives on through their son's pivotal role in salvation history and their own example of unwavering faith in the face of doubt and difficulty[5][6].
evening_commemorations.ai_legend: Zechariah stood before the altar, his hands trembling as he held the censer. The weight of his priestly duties felt heavier than usual, for today he had been chosen by lot to enter the sanctuary and burn incense before the Lord. As the fragrant smoke rose, Zechariah's heart was filled with a mixture of awe and sorrow. He and his beloved wife Elizabeth had prayed for years for a child, but now in their old age, hope seemed lost. Suddenly, a brilliant light filled the sanctuary, and an angel appeared at the right side of the altar. Zechariah stumbled backward, his eyes wide with fear. The angel spoke, his voice resonating with divine authority: "Do not be afraid, Zechariah. Your prayer has been heard. Your wife Elizabeth will bear you a son, and you shall call his name John." Zechariah's mind reeled. Could it be true? After all these years? His doubt bubbled to the surface, and he questioned the angel: "How shall I know this? For I am an old man, and my wife is advanced in years." The angel's countenance grew stern. "I am Gabriel. I stand in the presence of God, and I was sent to speak to you and to bring you this good news. And behold, you will be silent and unable to speak until the day that these things take place, because you did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their time." In an instant, Zechariah felt his tongue grow heavy and immobile. As he left the sanctuary, he could only gesture to the waiting crowd, unable to share the miraculous news. For nine long months, Zechariah remained silent. Yet in that silence, his faith grew. He watched in wonder as Elizabeth's belly swelled with new life. He saw the joy in her eyes and felt the kicks of their unborn son. In the quiet of his heart, Zechariah's doubt transformed into unwavering trust in God's promise. When the child was born and the time came to name him, Zechariah's relatives assumed the boy would bear his father's name. But Elizabeth insisted, "No; he shall be called John." Confused, they turned to Zechariah, who asked for a writing tablet. With a steady hand, he wrote, "His name is John." At that moment, Zechariah's tongue was loosed, and he began to speak, praising God. The words that had been bottled up for months poured forth in a beautiful prophecy, blessing the Lord and foretelling the great purpose of his son's life. Zechariah's faithful silence had prepared him for this moment of joyous proclamation. Through his experience, he learned that God's promises, no matter how impossible they may seem, are always fulfilled in His perfect time.
evening_commemorations.ai_one_sentence: Elizabeth and Zechariah were the righteous and devout parents of John the Baptist, known for their faithfulness to God despite years of childlessness, and their role in raising the prophetic forerunner who prepared the way for Jesus Christ.
evening_commemorations.ai_quote: "Both of them were righteous before God, walking blamelessly in all the commandments and statutes of the Lord."[1][2][5]
evening_commemorations.ai_verse: "And they were both righteous before God, walking blamelessly in all the commandments and statutes of the Lord."

mass_readings.text:
10 Hear the word of the Lord,
    you rulers of Sodom!
Give ear to the teaching of our God,
    you people of Gomorrah!
11 “What to me is the multitude of your sacrifices?
    says the Lord;
I have had enough of burnt offerings of rams
    and the fat of well-fed beasts;
I do not delight in the blood of bulls,
    or of lambs, or of goats.

12 “When you come to appear before me,
    who has required of you
    this trampling of my courts?
13 Bring no more vain offerings;
    incense is an abomination to me.
New moon and Sabbath and the calling of convocations—
    I cannot endure iniquity and solemn assembly.
14 Your new moons and your appointed feasts
    my soul hates;
they have become a burden to me;
    I am weary of bearing them.
15 When you spread out your hands,
    I will hide my eyes from you;
even though you make many prayers,
    I will not listen;
    your hands are full of blood.
16 Wash yourselves; make yourselves clean;
    remove the evil of your deeds from before my eyes;
cease to do evil,
17     learn to do good;
seek justice,
    correct oppression;
bring justice to the fatherless,
    plead the widow's cause.

18 “Come now, let us reason together, says the Lord:
though your sins are like scarlet,
    they shall be as white as snow;
though they are red like crimson,
    they shall become like wool.
19 If you are willing and obedient,
    you shall eat the good of the land;
20 but if you refuse and rebel,
    you shall be eaten by the sword;
    for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.”

Psalm 32

Beati quorum

1 Blessed is the one whose unrighteousness is forgiven,*

and whose sin is covered.

2 Blessed is the one to whom the Lord imputes no sin,*

and in whose spirit there is no guile.

3 For while I held my tongue, my bones wasted away;*

I ceased not from groaning all the day long.

4 For your hand was heavy upon me day and night,*

and I was dried up and withered, as in the drought of summer.

5 Then I acknowledged my sin unto you,*

and I did not hide my iniquity.

6 I said, "I will confess my sins unto the Lord";*

and so you forgave the wickedness of my sin.

7 For this reason shall all the godly make their prayers unto you at a time when you may be found;*

when the great floodwaters rise, they shall not reach them.

8 You are my hiding-place; you shall preserve me from trouble;*

you shall encompass me with songs of deliverance.

9 "I will instruct you and teach you in the way that you should go,*

and I will guide you with my eye.

10 Do not be like the horse and mule, which have no understanding,*

whose mouths must be held with bit and bridle, or else they will not come near you."

11 Great troubles remain for the ungodly;*

but mercy embraces those who trust in the Lord.

12 Be glad, O you righteous, and rejoice in the Lord;*

and be joyful, all who are true of heart.

Greeting

1 Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy,

To the church of the Thessalonians in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ:

2 Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

Thanksgiving

3 We ought always to give thanks to God for you, brothers, as is right, because your faith is growing abundantly, and the love of every one of you for one another is increasing. 4 Therefore we ourselves boast about you in the churches of God for your steadfastness and faith in all your persecutions and in the afflictions that you are enduring.

The Judgment at Christ's Coming

5 This is evidence of the righteous judgment of God, that you may be considered worthy of the kingdom of God, for which you are also suffering— 6 since indeed God considers it just to repay with affliction those who afflict you, 7 and to grant relief to you who are afflicted as well as to us, when the Lord Jesus is revealed from heaven with his mighty angels 8 in flaming fire, inflicting vengeance on those who do not know God and on those who do not obey the gospel of our Lord Jesus. 9 They will suffer the punishment of eternal destruction, away from the presence of the Lord and from the glory of his might, 10 when he comes on that day to be glorified in his saints, and to be marveled at among all who have believed, because our testimony to you was believed. 11 To this end we always pray for you, that our God may make you worthy of his calling and may fulfill every resolve for good and every work of faith by his power, 12 so that the name of our Lord Jesus may be glorified in you, and you in him, according to the grace of our God and the Lord Jesus Christ.

Jesus and Zacchaeus

19 He entered Jericho and was passing through. 2 And behold, there was a man named Zacchaeus. He was a chief tax collector and was rich. 3 And he was seeking to see who Jesus was, but on account of the crowd he could not, because he was small in stature. 4 So he ran on ahead and climbed up into a sycamore tree to see him, for he was about to pass that way. 5 And when Jesus came to the place, he looked up and said to him, “Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for I must stay at your house today.” 6 So he hurried and came down and received him joyfully. 7 And when they saw it, they all grumbled, “He has gone in to be the guest of a man who is a sinner.” 8 And Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, “Behold, Lord, the half of my goods I give to the poor. And if I have defrauded anyone of anything, I restore it fourfold.” 9 And Jesus said to him, “Today salvation has come to this house, since he also is a son of Abraham. 10 For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.”

commemorations.name: Thursday after the Twenty-first Sunday after Pentecost, or the Twentieth Sunday after Trinity (Proper 26)
commemorations.collect: Grant us, Lord, not to be anxious about earthly things, but to love things heavenly; and even now, as we live among things that are passing away, to hold fast to those that shall endure; through Jesus Christ our Lord, who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever. Amen.

commemorations.name: William Temple, Archbishop of Canterbury and Teacher of the Faith, 1944
commemorations.collect: O God, our heavenly Father, you raised up your faithful servant William Temple to be Bishop and pastor in your Church and to feed your flock: Give abundantly to all pastors the gifts of your Holy Spirit, that they may minister in your household as true servants of Christ and stewards of your divine mysteries; through Jesus Christ our Lord, who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.
ai_bullet_points: Born in 1881, William Temple was the son of an Archbishop of Canterbury and served as Bishop of Manchester (1921-1929), Archbishop of York (1929-1942), and Archbishop of Canterbury (1942-1944)[1][7].
Temple was a brilliant theologian and communicator, writing influential works like "Christus Veritas" that explored the relationship between Creation and Redemption[3][4].
He was a passionate advocate for social and economic reform, championing the poor and helping lay foundations for the modern welfare state through works like "Christianity and Social Order"[2][4].
Temple played a crucial role in the ecumenical movement, working to bridge gaps between Christian denominations and contributing to the formation of the World Council of Churches[1][2].

As Archbishop of Canterbury during World War II, Temple emphasized Christian unity in the face of global crisis and worked tirelessly to address social issues, ultimately dying of exhaustion in 1944[1][3][7].
commemorations.ai_hagiography: William Temple, born in Exeter in 1881, was a towering figure in the Church of England and a beacon of Christian leadership in the 20th century. As the son of Frederick Temple, who would later become Archbishop of Canterbury, William was steeped in the Anglican tradition from his earliest days. His intellectual prowess was evident from a young age, leading him to excel at Oxford University, where he graduated with first-class honors in classics[1]. Temple's academic career began at Queen's College, Oxford, where he lectured in philosophy from 1904 to 1910. During this time, he was ordained as a priest in 1909, marking the beginning of his formal ministry within the Church. His leadership qualities and innovative thinking soon became apparent as he took on the role of headmaster at Repton School from 1910 to 1914[7]. It was here that Temple began to develop his unique approach to education and social reform, which would characterize his later work. In 1914, Temple became the rector of St. James's, Piccadilly, where he founded the Life and Liberty movement. This initiative aimed to revitalize the Church of England by promoting greater autonomy and democratic governance within the institution[7]. His efforts in this regard were instrumental in shaping the modern structure of the Anglican Church, demonstrating his ability to effect meaningful change from within the established order. Temple's rise through the ecclesiastical ranks was swift and marked by significant achievements. He served as Canon of Westminster from 1919 to 1921, before being appointed Bishop of Manchester in 1921. In this role, he continued to advocate for social reform and ecumenical cooperation. His leadership and vision were further recognized when he became Archbishop of York in 1929, a position he held until 1942[7]. The pinnacle of Temple's career came in 1942 when he was enthroned as Archbishop of Canterbury. Despite the brevity of his tenure, cut short by his untimely death in 1944, Temple left an indelible mark on both the Church and society. His most famous work, "Christianity and Social Order," published in 1942, articulated a compelling vision for a just post-war society. This seminal text is credited with helping to lay the foundations for the modern welfare state in Britain[4]. Temple's commitment to social justice was encapsulated in his oft-quoted statement: "The Church is the only organization that does not exist for itself, but for those who live outside of it"[4]. Throughout his life, Temple was a prolific writer and thinker, producing works that spanned philosophy, theology, and social ethics. His Gifford Lectures, published as "Nature, Man, and God" in 1934, demonstrated his ability to engage with complex philosophical ideas while remaining grounded in Christian doctrine[10]. Temple's legacy extends beyond his writings; he was instrumental in founding the Council of Christians and Jews, promoting interfaith dialogue at a critical time in history. His influence also led to the formation of the British Council of Churches and the World Council of Churches, cementing his role as a key figure in the ecumenical movement[4]. William Temple's life and work continue to inspire Christians and social reformers alike, embodying the ideal of a faith that is both intellectually rigorous and practically engaged in the betterment of society.
commemorations.ai_legend: On a sunny August day, Archbishop William Temple and his wife Frances found themselves enjoying a picnic overlooking the serene beauty of Buttermere Lake. As they gazed upon the breathtaking landscape, their conversation turned to matters of faith and the afterlife. Inspired by the magnificent view before them, Archbishop Temple turned to his wife and quoted from memory a passage from Scripture: "Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither hath it entered into the heart of man what good things God hath prepared for them that love him." He paused for a moment, allowing the words to sink in, before adding with a touch of his characteristic wit and wisdom, "If it's something better than this, then it must be pretty good." In this simple exchange, Temple revealed the depth of his faith, his ability to find profound meaning in everyday moments, and his gift for making complex theological concepts accessible. Even in a casual setting, he seamlessly wove together Scripture, natural beauty, and personal reflection, demonstrating the integration of his faith with all aspects of life[7]. This anecdote not only showcases Temple's deep spirituality but also his humility and ability to appreciate the present moment while contemplating the eternal. It offers a glimpse into the character of a man who, despite his lofty position, could find God's truth and beauty in a simple lakeside picnic.
commemorations.ai_lesser_feasts_and_fasts: William Temple was a renowned teacher and preacher who served as Archbishop of Canterbury during the difficult days of the Second World War. His writings reflect a robust social theology that engages the challenges of modern industrialized society. Temple was born on October 15th, 1881. His father, Dr. Frederick Temple, Bishop of Exeter and then of London, became Archbishop of Canterbury when William was fifteen. Growing up at the heart of the Church of England, William’s love for it was deep and lifelong. Endowed with a brilliant mind, Temple took a first-class honors degree in classics and philosophy at Oxford, where he was then elected Fellow of Queen’s College. At the age of twenty-nine he became headmaster of Repton School, and then, in quick succession, rector of St. James’s Church, Piccadilly, Bishop of Manchester, and Archbishop of York. Though he was never subject to poverty himself, he developed a passion for social justice which shaped his words and his actions. He owed this passion to a profound belief in the Incarnation. He wrote that in Jesus Christ God took flesh and dwelt among us, and, as a consequence, “the personality of every man and woman is sacred.” In 1917, Temple resigned from St. James’s, Piccadilly, to devote his energies to the “Life and Liberty” movement for reform within the Church of England. Two years later, an Act of Parliament led to the setting up of the Church Assembly, which for the first time gave the laity a voice in Church matters. As bishop, and later as archbishop, Temple committed himself to seeking “the things which pertain to the Kingdom of God.” He understood the Incarnation as giving worth and meaning not only to individuals but to all of life. He therefore took the lead in establishing the Conference on Christian Politics, Economics, and Citizenship (COPEC), held 1924. In 1940, he convened the great Malvern Conference to reflect on the social reconstruction that would be needed in Britain once the Second World War was over. At the same time, he was a prolific writer on theological, ecumenical, and social topics, and his two-volume Readings in St. John’s Gospel, written in the early days of the war, rapidly became a spiritual classic. In 1942, Temple was appointed Archbishop of Canterbury and reached an even wider audience through his wartime radio addresses and newspaper articles. However, the scope of his responsibilities and the pace he set himself took their toll. On October 26th, 1944, he died at Westgate-on-Sea, Kent, after only two and a half years at Canterbury.
commemorations.ai_one_sentence: William Temple (1881-1944) was an influential English Anglican priest who served as Archbishop of Canterbury from 1942 to 1944, known for his scholarly writing, social activism, ecumenical efforts, and significant contributions to Christian social thought, particularly his work "Christianity and Social Order" which influenced the development of the British welfare state.
commemorations.ai_quote: "The Church is the only society that exists for the benefit of those who are not its members." - William Temple [1][4]
commemorations.ai_verse: "The Word became flesh and dwelt among us, and we have seen his glory, glory as of the only Son from the Father, full of grace and truth."

Give ear to the teaching of our God,

    says the Lord;
I have had enough of burnt offerings of rams

I do not delight in the blood of bulls,

they have become a burden to me;
    I am weary of bearing them.
15 When you spread out your hands,
    I will hide my eyes from you;
even though you make many prayers,
    I will not listen;
    your hands are full of blood.
16 Wash yourselves; make yourselves clean;
    remove the evil of your deeds from before my eyes;
cease to do evil,
17     learn to do good;
seek justice,
    correct oppression;
bring justice to the fatherless,
    plead the widow's cause.

18 “Come now, let us reason together, says the Lord:
though your sins are like scarlet,
    they shall be as white as snow;
though they are red like crimson,
    they shall become like wool.
19 If you are willing and obedient,
    you shall eat the good of the land;
20 but if you refuse and rebel,
    you shall be eaten by the sword;
    for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.”

Psalm 32

Beati quorum

1 Blessed is the one whose unrighteousness is forgiven,*

and whose sin is covered.

2 Blessed is the one to whom the Lord imputes no sin,*

and in whose spirit there is no guile.

3 For while I held my tongue, my bones wasted away;*

I ceased not from groaning all the day long.

4 For your hand was heavy upon me day and night,*

and I was dried up and withered, as in the drought of summer.

5 Then I acknowledged my sin unto you,*

and I did not hide my iniquity.

6 I said, "I will confess my sins unto the Lord";*

and so you forgave the wickedness of my sin.

7 For this reason shall all the godly make their prayers unto you at a time when you may be found;*

when the great floodwaters rise, they shall not reach them.

8 You are my hiding-place; you shall preserve me from trouble;*

you shall encompass me with songs of deliverance.

9 "I will instruct you and teach you in the way that you should go,*

and I will guide you with my eye.

10 Do not be like the horse and mule, which have no understanding,*

whose mouths must be held with bit and bridle, or else they will not come near you."

11 Great troubles remain for the ungodly;*

but mercy embraces those who trust in the Lord.

12 Be glad, O you righteous, and rejoice in the Lord;*

and be joyful, all who are true of heart.

Greeting

1 Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy,

To the church of the Thessalonians in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ:

2 Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

Thanksgiving

3 We ought always to give thanks to God for you, brothers, as is right, because your faith is growing abundantly, and the love of every one of you for one another is increasing. 4 Therefore we ourselves boast about you in the churches of God for your steadfastness and faith in all your persecutions and in the afflictions that you are enduring.

The Judgment at Christ's Coming

5 This is evidence of the righteous judgment of God, that you may be considered worthy of the kingdom of God, for which you are also suffering— 6 since indeed God considers it just to repay with affliction those who afflict you, 7 and to grant relief to you who are afflicted as well as to us, when the Lord Jesus is revealed from heaven with his mighty angels 8 in flaming fire, inflicting vengeance on those who do not know God and on those who do not obey the gospel of our Lord Jesus. 9 They will suffer the punishment of eternal destruction, away from the presence of the Lord and from the glory of his might, 10 when he comes on that day to be glorified in his saints, and to be marveled at among all who have believed, because our testimony to you was believed. 11 To this end we always pray for you, that our God may make you worthy of his calling and may fulfill every resolve for good and every work of faith by his power, 12 so that the name of our Lord Jesus may be glorified in you, and you in him, according to the grace of our God and the Lord Jesus Christ.

Jesus and Zacchaeus

19 He entered Jericho and was passing through. 2 And behold, there was a man named Zacchaeus. He was a chief tax collector and was rich. 3 And he was seeking to see who Jesus was, but on account of the crowd he could not, because he was small in stature. 4 So he ran on ahead and climbed up into a sycamore tree to see him, for he was about to pass that way. 5 And when Jesus came to the place, he looked up and said to him, “Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for I must stay at your house today.” 6 So he hurried and came down and received him joyfully. 7 And when they saw it, they all grumbled, “He has gone in to be the guest of a man who is a sinner.” 8 And Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, “Behold, Lord, the half of my goods I give to the poor. And if I have defrauded anyone of anything, I restore it fourfold.” 9 And Jesus said to him, “Today salvation has come to this house, since he also is a son of Abraham. 10 For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.”

primary_evening_feast: Thursday after the Twenty-first Sunday after Pentecost, or the Twentieth Sunday after Trinity (Proper 26)
